description:
Phytophthora infestans T30-4 is a strain of the oomycete pathogen responsible for late blight disease in potatoes and tomatoes. It is a water mold that thrives in cool, moist conditions and can rapidly infect and destroy these important crop plants.

The T30-4 strain is a highly aggressive and virulent form of P. infestans that has been extensively studied due to its significant impact on global food security. It exhibits rapid growth, prolific asexual spore production, and the ability to overcome many host resistance genes, making it a persistent and challenging pathogen to manage.

Genome sequencing and comparative analyses have revealed that the T30-4 strain possesses a large, complex genome with a high proportion of repetitive elements and effector genes that enable it to evade plant immune responses. This genetic information has provided valuable insights into the evolutionary adaptations and virulence mechanisms of this devastating plant pathogen.

Ongoing research continues to explore the biology, epidemiology, and management strategies for controlling Phytophthora infestans T30-4 and other strains to mitigate the significant threat they pose to potato and tomato production worldwide.
